title: Homeless people were turned away from shelters as Typhoon Hagibis hit Japan
text:
A Japanese evacuation shelter turned away two homeless people as Typhoon Hagibis approached on Saturday, because they did not have addresses in the area.

Staff at the evacuation centre in Tokyo's Taito ward refused to let the homeless pair inside as the powerful storm neared, insisting the shelter only catered for residents of the ward, officials said.

'The wind was strong and it was raining, and I wanted them to let me in,' a 64-year-old homeless man told the Asahi newspaper.

He said he arrived at the shelter on Saturday morning and was asked to write down his name and address. When he said he had an address on the northern island of Hokkaido, he was refused entry because he was not a resident of the ward.

Evacuated residents sit inside a shelter in Tokyo as they wait out Typhoon Hagibis on Saturday

A woman walks past a home destroyed by Typhoon Hagibis in Nagano, Japan on Tuesday

The man spent the night under a plastic umbrella, partially shielded beneath the eaves of a building, the newspaper said.

Another homeless man was also turned away from the shelter, which was inside a school, when he visited it that afternoon.

Hagibis unleashed fierce winds and unprecedented rain that triggered landslides and caused dozens of rivers to burst their banks when it made landfall on the south coast of Honshu island on Saturday evening.

The storm is believed to have killed at least 69 people across Japan, with the death toll expected to rise as the desperate search for survivors entered its third day on Tuesday. At least a dozen people are still unaccounted for.

Rescuers attempt to reach a car found in a river in Koriyama, Fukushima prefecture, Japan

A pair walk past homes and debris littering the area near to where a river burst its banks

Two men remove muddy items from their flood-damaged homes in Koriyama, Fukushima prefecture on Tuesday

Reports said a homeless man was found dead near a flooded river in Tokyo this morning. Police suspect he lived near the river and had drowned in the floods.

According to the government, some 1,100 people sleep rough in Tokyo, accounting for a quarter of the nation's homeless.

'But the actual figure may be larger as new types of homeless people who stay at internet cafe or other facilities are emerging,' a government official said.

Social media lit up with criticism of the Taito ward following the incident on Saturday, with many people denouncing its actions as a violation of human rights.

'Is this a country that's going to host the Olympics in Tokyo?' one man asked on Twitter. 'People from abroad would see this and think this is a terrible country.'

An elderly woman is helped through a road blocked by debris by a rescuer in Koriyama

A home in Nagano destroyed by the powerful typhoon is surrounded by debris and floodwater

Wooden planks and metal sheets litter the ground in the wake of Typhoon Hagibis in Koriyama

An area in Nagano is flooded with murky water after the embankment of the Chikuma River broke due to Typhoon Hagibis

Prime Minister Shinzo Abe also insisted evacuation centres should welcome everyone when he was asked by an opposition member of parliament about the incident.

'Evacuation centres should let anyone in who has come to evacuate,' he said. 'We will look into the facts and take appropriate measures.'

Taito ward has said it will now review its procedures and 'consider measures to support all people' at the the time of a disaster.

'We deeply apologise that we dealt with people without addresses insufficiently so that they could not stay at the shelter,' the mayor of the ward, Yukuo Hattori, said in a statement.

'We will cooperate with related parties and consider measures to support all the people at the time of a disaster.'

Hagibis unleashed fierce winds and unprecedented rain that triggered landslides and caused dozens of rivers to burst their banks when it made landfall

The storm is believed to have killed at least 69 people across Japan, with at least a dozen missing

A man in rubber boots attempts to clear mud from the street of a Nagano neighbourhood destroyed by Typhoon Hagibis

Homes were ripped apart by the powerful storm which made landfall on Honshu island on Saturday

Groups of rescuers wearing goggles and snorkels searched for survivors on Monday while making their way in waist-high water in Nagano, central Japan, where the Chikuma River inundated swaths of land.

More than 110,000 police officers, firefighters, soldiers and coastguard personnel, as well as some 100 helicopters were mobilised for rescue operations, Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga said.

Around 7.3 million people were placed under non-compulsory evacuation orders after Typhoon Hagibis hit Japan's south coast on Saturday.

The storm crashed into the nation's main Honshu island at 7pm before barrelling into Izu, a peninsula southwest of Tokyo, the Japan Meteorological Agency said.

Even before it made landfall, Hagibis caused enormous disruption, forcing the cancellation of two Rugby World Cup matches, delaying the Japanese Grand Prix and grounding all flights in the Tokyo region.
description: Staff at an evacuation centre in Tokyo's Taito ward refused to let two homeless people inside as Typhoon Hagibis neared on Saturday because they didn't have addresses in the area.
